narratives-archive-text: From 2017 to the present the Margarites Oral Narratives team has conducted over 100 interviews of mainly Margarites residents with a focus on life histories, family histories and the arts and practices of the last century. A number of interviews from the 80s conducted by Maria Padouva, president of Rodakas, will be added to this archive. The entire interview archive is being transcribed and edited, new interviews are constantly being added to it as the team continues its action.
photo-archive-text: From 2017 to the present day the Margarites Oral Narratives team has collected dozens of photographs of the village and its inhabitants provided by the private collections of the village's people, taken from the early 20th century onwards.
stone-house-text: Brief reference to the physiognomy of the Margarites community until the middle of the 20th century and the form of the stone-built residence.
about1-text1: It was created in 2017 by a group of residents of the village of Margarites in Rethymnon. The aim was to record the life histories of the oldest residents of the Community.
about1-text2: A main motive for the archive creation was the realisation that as the generation of people who in 2017 were over 80 years old was close to the end, the living memory of historic events during the World War II, the Occupation, the civil war and to this day, is also going to be lost. At the same time, the living memory of social events and relations during the period that Margarites and the nearby communities were populous is getting lost, a time when livelihood was based on agricultural production, pottery making and when most transactions were based on product exchange. Moreover, with this generation the living memory of professions and daily life practices ends, as well as the memory of the settlement layout before the middle of the 20th century.
about1-text3: A powerful motive behind our effort was also the need to capture the speech of the people who narrate. A voice that is usually unaffected by formal education and which, as far as content, vocabulary and prosody is concerned, echoes the era of Orality, an era when knowledge, information, action, emotion and also every kind of relationship emerged and was captured through the living and continuous oral narratives of the Community.
about2-text1: The Community of Margarites is the connecting thread of Rodakas. The history, the people, the social/demographic, institutional and cultural changes that emerge through the narratives of its inhabitants were the first and most important common ground and interest of the group; they gave motivation and provided the inspiration for its creation and aims.
about2-text2: Rodakas set as its primary goal the creation of the Archive of Oral History, as well as the Photographic Archive of the Margarites Community, which will be useful and convenient for research, and at the same time it will constitute a legacy and a memory deposit for the younger generation, whether they are residents or come from Margarites and the surrounding communities. The same applies to the stone building, weaving and pottery workshops. Knowledge and knowhow originate in the Community, is accessible to the wider public and eventually comes back to the Community.
members1-text: I was born in Athens in 1959. My mother came from Margarites and my father from Orthe in Mylopotamos. I graduated from the Faculty of Media and Modern Greek Studies of the Philosophical School of the University of Ioannina and then I studied at the ECOLE DES HAUTES ETUDES EN SCIENCES SOCIALES, in Paris where I received the Diploma in Ethnology. I continued my postgraduate studies at PARIS 1 PANTHEON-SORBONNE University where I received the D.E.A. from the field of Byzantine and Post-Byzantine History. My research in the field of Ethnology and History was carried out with reference to the villages of Mylopotamos in Crete and especially Margarites and for this reason I started the first interviews with residents of the area in the 1980s. The subject of my research was the Habitation and Family in Mountainous and Semi-mountainous Mylopotamos. During this time, I worked as an ethnologist in research programs at Panteion University and the Museum of Cretan Ethnology, in collaboration with Christoforos Vallianos, in Voros of Heraklion, on the subject of Ceramic Art in the villages of Crete. (Especially Margarites and Thrapsano). I currently work in Public Secondary Education as a philologist since 1994 and I have two children. In the summer of 2017, I settled in Margarites and transferred to the Mylopotamos Garazos High School, of which I am still the director. One of the most important reasons for which I sought to return to my place of origin was to continue ethnographic recording, collecting oral history, family and life histories, as well as recording expertise and practices that are no longer practiced in terms of arts, the processing of products, the cultivation of the land... I also had a strong conviction that these processes should be the subject of teamwork by members of the Community itself that will be materialised in the form of archives, but also through live workshops, a way of connecting with the past, the local History and the identity of the Community itself and its members.
members6-text: My name is Fassouli Irini. I was born and live in Margarites. I am married and have three children. I am professionally active in the village in tourism. I love my village and I consider important the promotion of local history and the village’s continuity through the young people. I wish to realize these goals through my work at Rodakas. I am grateful that in the difficult times we live I am given this opportunity.
members7-text: I was born in Athens to parents originally from Margarites. I studied Theology at the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki and did postgraduate studies specializing in Church History. I attended seminars on Greek paleography at the MIET and at the Patriarchal Foundation for Patriarchal Studies and historical sciences at the Center for Byzantine Studies of the National Research Foundation. My research interests are in the area of ecclesiastical history, the history of books and libraries with an emphasis on ecclesiastical archives and libraries. I worked at the 9th Ephorate of Byzantine Antiquities (Thessaloniki). Since 1992 I have been living and working in Crete. I worked as a bookstore employee, as a teacher in secondary education, as an excavation technician in Eleftherna and from 1998 until today as a librarian in the rare books department of the library of the University of Crete. From 1995 to 1998 I participated in the council of the Community of Margarites. My participation in Rodakas is an opportunity to combine the study of our oral tradition and material culture with bibliographical and archival research.
members11-text: Born in Athens, originally from Margarites, I went from being a visitor to a resident of the village in 2020. I am a graduate of the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering of the National Technical University of Athens. Challenged by the future of the isolated small communities in the Greek countryside, I chose to attend and complete the Interdisciplinary Master's Program "Environment and Development of Mountainous Areas" of the National Technical University of Athens, in which I was involved in the study of scenarios for flood prevention stations in the area Rethymnon. To me, Rodakas is, apart from a personal bet, a political position as an attempt to support the small community and strengthen the local production of culture and knowledge.
multimedia1-text: How were the solid residential units with the tall outer walls that close 'like a pomegranate', the residences of Margarites, built? Which families lived in which neighborhoods and what were their stories? How did the builders extract the stone and how was a house built by the local craftsmen? These are the topics that "The Threshold of Memory" 2019, the second documentary of the Oral History Group (Rodakas), talks about. This record is based on oral testimonies and is a journey through the public spaces and a reminiscence of the ancestral home and the childhood years of the village residents.
multimedia2-text: A section of the archival material (videos, interviews, photos) from the life histories records of the older residents of Margarites was used to create the documentary "Harder years, happier years", focusing on the important personal relationships and the historical and social events that affected the lives of the people who narrate. The decision to make the documentary arose from the team’s need to communicate its activity and to contribute in raising awareness about the importance of storytelling and the value of memory in establishing cultural identity and social cohesion.

stoneworkshop.introtext: Walking through the gorges of Margarites and Eleutherna, along the slopes where the mitata of Psiloritis are found, talking with the instructors, observing and taking notes, coexisting and creating new works — just before July 2025 comes to an end, we engage in a priceless exchange with the Community, the landscape, and the environment.
stoneworkshop.info1: Theory and practice of traditional stone masonry in Margarites, Mylopotamos, with masters Yiannis Alefantinos and Kostis Vergianakis as instructors. We learn about the construction and restoration of dry stone walls, the restoration of stone walls, the replacement of carved door and window frames, pointing and mortars using natural materials, as well as the extraction and carving of local stone.

stoneworkshop.instructorBio1: Yiannis Alefantinos was born in 1956, in Tzannakiana, a settlement of the Community of Margarites Mylopotamos. His grandfather, like his father Giannis and his paternal uncles, George and Nikos, were all stonemasons and were involved in construction as well as stone sculpting. He studied with them from his childhood. He learned from a child the techniques of mining and the types of local stone, the building of the stone wall, the chiselling and the construction of doors, as well as the sculpting of the stone. He built "with couple" the master Giorgis Gerovasakis, in the Despotic of the Metropolis of Rethymnon, he participated in the construction of the churches of the Prophet Elias in Ancient Eleftherna, of the Holy Trinity in Angeliana, of Agios Georgios in Humeri, of Agios Spyridon in Piguniana, in the construction of the school in the village of Chonos Rethymnon. He also worked on the restoration of the Monastery of Agios Ioannis in Bali as well as on the restoration projects of the Fortezza of Rethymno and the mansion-tower of the doctor Emmanuel Mathioudakis in Angeliana. He was involved in the construction of a large number of stone-built houses until the 90s. When the use of stone as a basic building material decreased, he continued working in the reconstruction and restoration of stone structures, in pointing and plastering of stone masonry. He used local soils and experimented with them for the strength and tightness of joints and plasters. He was interested in solidity as much as the aesthetic effect and therefore used the knowledge from the tradition of his ancestors and his own great technical experience. At the same time, as he respected and always had a great interest in tradition, he created a remarkable written archive of records of his fellow villagers, but also of historical events that he experienced and that characterized his time. Yiannis Alefantinos is the last stone mason in Margarites, who knows and applies the local building techniques, which were used for centuries by the stone masons in this village, creating its excellent characteristic image. Since the first stone workshop in the summer of 2020, Yiannis Alefantinos has participated as an instructor in all the stonework restoration workshops of RODAKAS. He also took part in the research of the Margarites Oral Narratives Group for the historical recording of the families and homes of the Margarites Community and helped significantly in the realization of the documentary of the Margarites Oral Narratives Group: "The Threshold of Memory".
stoneworkshop.instructorBio2: Kostas Vergianakis was born in 1962 in the Alpha settlement of Mylopotamos municipality, a village with a rich cultural heritage. In the settlement, due to the rich subsoil in porolite deposits, the famous Alfopetra, a stone easy to process and resistant to its use in constructions, there were developed many famous and remarkable, for the time in which each lived, masters in building with stone. In 1985, Kostas Vergianakis was taught the art of stonework by two of these "masters", Charalampos and Yiannis Vergianakis. Craftsmen with a significant legacy in the field of stone constructions. His acquaintance and collaboration with Manolis Skevakis, stonemason - sculptor, in 1990 pushed him to see the construction of stone from another angle, while then the professional collaboration with Konstantinos Tzanoudakis or Tzanoudokostas from the village of Langa in the municipality of Mylopotamos, master craftsman equally renowned for his building technique, he further expanded his knowledge and construction perception. Today, Kostas Vergianakis follows the same path that all the above showed him. Each one individually contributed in his own way to the formation of his character as a "master craftsman" with valuable construction experience. And he, in turn, tries to pass on his knowledge and the art he possesses, to anyone who is willing to learn.

loomworkshop.title: Rodakas Weaving Workshop in Margarites
introtext: Ένας ακόμη κύκλος του Ρόδακα στην τέχνη της Υφαντικής, με τη χρηματοδότηση του Κοινωφελούς Ιδρύματος Ιωάννη Σ. Λάτση,

Σε τελάρα με δασκάλα τη Βασιλεία Ανηψητάκη, όπου θα μετρήσουμε για να τοποθετήσουμε το σχέδιο, θα συνδυάσουμε και θα αναμείξουμε χρώματα, θα μάθουμε να υφαίνουμε ευθύγραμμα, καμπύλα και ποικίλων σχημάτων μοτίβα και σχέδια με διαφορετικές υφές.

Στους αργαλειούς, με δασκάλα τη Δέσποινα Σωμάκη όπου θα εξασκηθούμε σε διαφορετικούς τύπους υφαντών, με το λεπτό νήμα στο στημόνι και στο υφάδι αλλά και με το χοντρό στημόνι και κουρέλια για υφάδι, για τη δημιουργία κάθε είδους, σχεδιου και  χρήσης υφάσματος.
Κι ακόμη ο δάσκαλος Μανώλης Κουράτορας θα μας δείξει το Διάσιμο (προετοιμασία, διευθέτηση και τύλιγμα των νημάτων στο «αντί» που θα αποτελέσουν το στημόνι  των υφαντών μας)
Και η δασκάλα Κατερίνα Κορρέ θα μάς δείξει τη βαφική τέχνη και τις πολλές αποχρώσεις που μπορούν να δώσουν δύο πολύ σημαντικά για τη βαφική αν και τόσο ταπεινά φυτά: Η «Ακονιζά(έ)» και η Ξυνίδα.

instructors.name: Despina Pantelaki-Somaki
bio: I was born in Chania to devout and honorable parents. My father, Tilemachos Pantelakis, was a traffic officer in Chania, and my mother, Sofia, was from Heraklion and worked at Eleni Kastrinogianni’s weaving mill. My mother influenced me, and I grew to love the art of weaving. At sixteen, I married Emmanouil Somakis, a Navy officer, and we had two children, Tilemachos Antonios and Stefania.

I worked in various fields—making wedding favors, sewing buttons, stringing pearls in jewelry stores, selling frozen goods and oranges in farmers' markets. However, I always longed to weave! The sounds, the colors, the smell of the threads, the final product enchanted me… I promised myself that at 40, no matter what I had done before, I would set up a loom, and I did it!
At first, my choice to become a weaver was met with disdain, but I persevered. I am proud to be a weaver!

Despina Pantelaki-Somaki has been teaching weaving at the Lyceum of Greek Women in Chania for five years. Her woven works have been acquired by the fashion house Chanel, and Dior has also shown interest. She collaborates with the Greek brand Gaenus by Eftychia Sarri in London and other renowned fashion houses.

instructors.name: Vasileia Anipsitaki
bio: I was born and raised in Sitia, Crete. I studied at the School of Architecture of A.U.Th. Alongside my professional career (1980–2025), I attended lessons in: Painting with Ms. Irini Kourtidi and Mr. Giorgos Rorris; Encaustic painting (painting with heated wax, known from the Fayum portraits) with Ms. Katerina Perimeni (Benaki Museum); Weaving with Ms. Sofia Tsourinaki (SEN); Fresco painting with Mr. Angelos Mplias (Benaki Museum); Arabic Calligraphy with Ms. Irini Gonou (Benaki Museum). I have presented my work in group and solo exhibitions:
• Group exhibition in Terlizzi, Italy with Fayum works (2013)
• Solo exhibition at ‘Dielefsis’ Cultural Center with Fayum works (2013)
• Solo exhibition at the Cultural Center of Sitia Municipality with Fayum and oil paintings (2014)
• Group exhibition at the Cultural Center of Sitia Municipality with paintings and weaving works (2017)
• Group exhibition at the Cultural Center of Sitia Municipality with paintings (2019)
• Solo exhibition at Arte Visione Art Hall with paintings, weaving, calligraphy, and encaustic works (2022)
• Group exhibition titled “The Chronicle of Art” at Arte Visione Art Hall (2022) and at METHI, Heraklion, Crete
• Solo exhibition at V. Kornaros Cultural Center in Sitia, Crete with weaving and calligraphy works (2023)
• Group exhibition at V. Kornaros Cultural Center in Sitia, Crete with weaving works (2024)
• Group Exhibition of Weaving Handicrafts at METHI Heraklion (2024)
• Group Exhibition of Weaving Handicrafts at the Municipal Gallery of Kallithea “Sofia Laskaridou” (2024)

My profession is Architecture, which coexists and collaborates with many different arts. I am influenced by the Bauhaus movement (1919–1933 in Germany), which merged the inspiration and skills of artists and craftsmen, sometimes leading to works and everyday objects of high aesthetics for mass production and use. I engage in various arts and crafts, without being a formal teacher. I am a lifelong learner, constantly discovering the magic in new artistic expressions and artifacts of the world. In weaving on a frame loom, I have gained much experience, so, as an advanced learner, I can, in the manner of mutual teaching, transmit basic knowledge and techniques to beginners in this ancient art, which continues to amaze us with its ingenuity and beauty.

instructors.name: Manolis Kouratoras
bio: I was born and raised in Agia, Rethymno, and after a long career, I have returned to live in my hometown. I graduated from the six-year Economic High School of Heraklion. I also graduated from the Panhellenic School of Spinning, Weaving, and Knitting and obtained a State Diploma as a Weaving Supervisor.

After being selected by my school, I received a scholarship to study in Italy at textile machinery manufacturing houses, where I specialized as an official assembler for SOMET weaving looms in Greece. I also underwent intensive training in various textile machines. I worked in Athens for a textile machinery agency and later served as a Supervisor at the major industry ELLINOROMANA in Thessaloniki and as Technical Director at PAPADIMITRIOU in Larissa.

Upon returning to Crete, I worked for years as the lead designer at Eleni Kastrinogianni’s business, a brand synonymous with traditional Cretan weaving. At the same time, I provided services as a designer and technician for smaller textile workshops in Heraklion.

I received official recognition as a certified instructor in weaving and participated in numerous training programs. I volunteered to establish and launch the weaving workshop at the Center for Special Needs Children, Agios Spyridon. Through the Crete Regional Operational Program, I taught a 150-hour course on ‘Modern Technology and Aesthetics in the Weaving Art.’ I also reconstructed a functional replica of Penelope’s loom, which was officially presented at the Heraklion Museum by the University of the Mountains, with distinguished guests including Professor and Sorbonne Rector Eleni Arveler.

I have been criticized for ‘patenting’ the production of the Cretan woven fabric using the three-beam technique with mechanical support. However, I believe this makes the fabric more accessible and affordable while keeping Cretan homes adorned with traditional textiles rather than foreign ones.
After retiring, I continue to share my experience and knowledge wherever I am asked to help revive and develop the weaving craft.

instructors.name: Manolis Kuratoras
bio: I was born and raised in Agia, Rethymno, and after a long career, I returned and live in my hometown. I graduated from the six-year Economic Gymnasium of Heraklion. I graduated and received a diploma from the Panhellenic School of Spinning, Weaving, and Knitting. I obtained a State Diploma as a Supervisor of Weaving.

After being selected by my school, I went to Italy on a scholarship to work for manufacturers of textile machinery and obtained the official qualification of Fitter for the Greek market in the weaving machines of SOMET. I specialized in intensive seminars on various spinning and weaving machines. I worked in Athens for a textile machinery dealership. I also worked as a Supervisor in the major industry ELLENOROMANA in Thessaloniki and as the Technical Director in the large industry PAPADIMITRIOU in Larissa.

Returning to Crete, I worked for years as the head and designer at the workshop of Eleni Kastrinogianni, a brand closely associated with the traditional weaving art of Crete. Simultaneously, I offered services as a designer and engineer to smaller crafts in Heraklion.

I have been recognized as an educator in the weaving specialty, and I have participated in many programs as a trainer. I voluntarily participated in the establishment and launch of the weaving workshop at the Center for Special Children, Agios Spyridon. Within the framework of the Operational Programme for Crete, I participated with 150 hours of teaching in the program Modern Technology and Aesthetics in Weaving Art. I also constructed and created a functional replica of Penelope's loom, which was officially presented at the Heraklion Museum by the University of the Mountains, with distinguished guests, including the professor and president of the University of Sorbonne, Eleni Arveler. Simultaneously, I started in Heraklion and after a few years, I joined LEADER 2 and relocated my craft industry for producing Cretan weavings and traditional costume items to Agia, Rethymno.

I have been accused of 'patenting' the production of Cretan Weavings using the technique of the three treadles with mechanical support. For me, this is right because it is economically affordable and offers the opportunity to decorate many homes better than imported textiles.
After my retirement, I offer my experience and knowledge wherever requested for the revival and development of Weaving Art.

instructors.name: Clarissa Joy Holmes
bio: Clarissa Holmes is from Montana, United States but living in Crete the last 8 years. Her long involvement with fabric design, coloring and pattern design led her back to the traditional ways of producing dyes and patterns.
In this workshop we will use local and traditional dyes to create and modify colors on wool.
In the second day of the workshop we will learn a technique called ‘eco-printing’ to create prints on your own fabric using plants and flowers.

Identification of materials and yarn analysis.

loomchildren.title: Weaving Workshop for Children
introtext: The children asked for it since last summer. So we started a weaving workshop for them, in the Rodakas loom area in Margarites.
programText: The workshop will be held twice a month over two weekends, engaging the children for 4 hours on Sunday of the first weekend and for 4 hours on Saturday and another 4 on Sunday of the second weekend.
The weekends are not necessarily consecutive; see dates below:
loomchildren.cost: A child can start attending the workshop at any time during the 6 months it will run.

instructors.name: Despina Pantelaki-Somaki
bio: I was born in Chania to devout and honorable parents. My father was Tilemachos Pantelakis, a traffic policeman in Chania, and my mother Sophia was from Heraklion. She worked at Eleni Kastrinogianni's weaving workshop. I inherited from my mother, who was a major influence, the love for the art of weaving. I got married at the age of sixteen to Emmanuel Somakis, a navy officer, and we had two children, Tilemachos Antonios and Stefania. I worked in various different jobs, making wedding favors, sewing buttons, stringing pearls in goldsmith workshops, and selling frozen goods and oranges in markets. However, I always wanted to work with a loom! The sound, the colors, the scent of the threads, and the end result enchanted me... I said that no matter what, at the age of 40, I would get a loom, and I made it happen! In the beginning, my choice to engage in weaving was met with disdain, but I didn't give up. I am proud to be a weaver!

Despina Pantelaki-Somaki has been teaching weaving at the Lyceum of Greek Women in Chania for five years. Her weavings have been acquired by Chanel and have attracted the interest of Dior. She collaborates with the Greek brand Gaenus, owned by Eftychia Sarri, in London, and with other important fashion houses.

instructors.name: Eirini Xanthioti
bio: Eirini Xanthioti holds a Bachelor’s degree in Business Administration and Education from Athens University of Business and Economics, with expertise in marketing and teaching proficiency in social and economic sciences. She studied theater in education at the School of Play in Athens and learned weaving and textile arts under Despina Somaki and Manolis Kouratoras at the Rodakas Loom Workshop in Crete, as well as under Sofia Tsourinaki at the Youth Education Association in Athens.

Eirini worked as a theater educator from 2015 to 2019 in various educational settings, including Aerini Poli and Perivoli sti Vari in Athens, as well as in summer camps and theater classes for children in Plakias and Sounio. She managed theater programs and facilitated workshops in permaculture and non-violence education for children aged 3 to 16. Recently, Eirini has led weaving workshops for children and beginners at the Rodakas Loom Workshop from March 2023 to January 2024 and organized weaving sessions at cultural festivals such as Fashion Revolution Week in Athens, Fields of Amalthia Festival, and European Wool Day in Metsovo. Eirini also completed an internship with Maria Sigma, assisting in fabric creation, and continues to lead workshops in art spaces like Peru Athens and Conseederate. Through her work, Eirini promotes arts education, sustainability, and creativity in community settings.

stonecarvingworkshop.introtext1: With the help and information of old Margarites' potters and with the Master of Rodaka's Stonework Workshops Yiannis Alefantinos, the restoration of the walls of an old Margarita pottery kiln begins on 10/27/23. It is a circular building with a special structure. The works concern the restoration of the worn stones and the construction and coating of the vessels' firing chamber.

stonecarvingworkshop.introtext2: The sculptor, Mr. Michalis Athanasakis, is coming to Margarites from October 28 to 30 to show us how to carve and create the reliefs on the stone, but also to talk to us about the art and techniques of mosaic.
